bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, August 20, [1941]

div1.p: Truby agrees that Cooke, Ames, and Jernegan should be included in the yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, August 20, [1941]
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Aug 20
Dear Dr Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter just came and
I have but a moment to say
that I approve placing Ames
by the side of Cooke on the porch.
While Ames did things later which
were not wise, he was the most
important man present from many
points of view. If the Board had
lost one or two cases the “Guinea Pig”
tests would have ended soon and
Reed knew it. No doubt a photo
of Ames can be obtained from his
widow. Kean, I think, knows her
address. His hair was coal black,
Jernegan should also be in
the picture.

I am still waiting to hear about
your Cuban trip.

closer.seg:
The faces in the
photo are familiar
but I can not help
you on that
